awd_titl_txt: CRII: III: Beyond Similarity Learning: Complementarity Learning for Contextual Behavior Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Given the complexity of human behaviors, it is difficult to develop a successful plan and make right decisions. Behavior data in fields such as social media, education, and academic research have been increasingly available for behavioral pattern discovery, decision making, and planning. Complementarity has been revealed of playing a significant role in many fields: partners need complementary strengths to do successful business; courses need complementary teaching materials to achieve effective student learning. Therefore, the representation of human behaviors should preserve the complementarity information rather than the similarity. The purpose of this project is to develop complementarity learning models to advance our understanding of human behaviors in dynamic, social, and spatiotemporal environments, and practically, to facilitate prediction, recommendation, and decision-making and planning processes towards the effectiveness of behaviors. This project will also support educational and outreach programs that will broaden participation in computer science. Open source software implementations of the new algorithms will be made available to the public, and will also serve as an educational tool for junior researchers. Research supervision and career mentoring will be made available to K-12 students through the development and publication, and a new course in data science and behavior modeling will be offered to undergraduate and graduate students.

This project will develop and evaluate novel behavior modeling methods that learn the representation of human behavior by preserving the structure of complementarity among the behavior's components. The idea is that decision makers are looking for not similar but complementary partners, resources, and conditions that provide extra power to make a behavior plan more effective.  In this project, principled metrics of complementarity that satisfy intuitive axioms will be proposed; complementarity representation learning methods will be developed, applied, and evaluated on prediction and recommendation tasks. In addition, this project will result in an online recommender system that facilitate young researchers for project teaming and planning.  The results will also be disseminated through tutorial and workshop organization at international conferences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this award includes five aspects:

- Graduate research

This award has supported three graduate research assistants (RAs). They are the advisees of the PI. One graduate RA has graduated with PhD and joined Amazon as a data scientist. The graduate RAs have published 19 research papers as the first author on 4 journal articles (TNNLS/TKDE/TIST/KAIS), 11 conference papers (3 WWW/2CIKM/2 EMNLP/KDD/ICDM/ACL/NAACL), and 4 workshop papers (4 DLG). One paper won the best paper award at the DLG workshop in 2020.

- Undergraduate research

This award has supported 5 undergraduate research assistants. They have published 5 research papers as the first author on 1 journal article (ACM CSUR), 2 conference papers (EMNLP/ICBK), and 2 workshop papers (BigDataTools/FEVER). One undergraduate RA won the travel award supported by Notre Dame Research for oral presentation at IEEE BigData.

- Conference tutorials

The PI has delivered tutorials at EMNLP 2021, KDD 2021, and two at KDD 2020 on the related topics.

- Curriculum development

The PI had developed a new course named Comptuational Behavior Modeling. It's been offered for every Spring semester from the year of 2019. The CIF feedback has been 5.0/5.0 for the last two offerings.

- Novel technologies

The research activities have created novel technologies for user behavior modeling and a new machine learning branch called "complementarity learning". A recent article "Deep Multi-modal Complementarity Learning" is under review with Major revision at IEEE TNNLS.

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/01/2021
Modified by: Meng Jiang
